content.raw: ok nice, the two issues I ran into are gone now. The loss of precision may matter more later on if we need to set contact or inertia params but so far for pose cmds, I think 6 decimal places is fine.
content.html: ok nice, the two issues I ran into are gone now. The loss of precision may matter more later on if we need to set contact or inertia params but so far for pose cmds, I think 6 decimal places is fine.

update.title: Pose commands from inspector

content.raw:
After banging my head against these for a while, I decided to take the simplest approach for now: force the minimum size of the inspector to be large enough to display 6-digit precision spin boxes: b6b48be

I also realized that lights can't be moved yet, so I disabled it.

I was also seeing some weird behaviour with the icons not updating and fixed that.

Finally, I noticed that there's a loss of precision when calling `ComponentInspector.OnPose`. Even though `double` types are being used on both the QML and the C++, when the number gets to C++ it's truncated. I researched a bit and it sounded like Qt5 should be doing the right thing, unless we compiled with the `-qreal float` option, which I think we didn't. I didn't look any further and left a `TODO` in the code.

---

Some of the things I tried, for the record:

* Forcing the side panel to expand as needed by the current numbers being displayed. It turned out to be complicated to propagate the desired width all the way from `Pose3d.qml` to the panel.
* Eliding the numbers - I started looking deep into the child components of `SpinBox` and ended up so deep, and accessing so many "private" members, that I think it would be risky to rely on this.
* Storing the actual number and the "display" number separately. The logic became quite involved, and in the end the behaviour may take users by surprised. I was storing the decimals that were hidden, and if the user edited the box when less decimals were displayed, I'd append those decimals to the command. But what if the user really meant to clean up those?
content.html:
After banging my head against these for a while, I decided to take the simplest approach for now: force the minimum size of the inspector to be large enough to display 6-digit precision spin boxes: b6b48be

I also realized that lights can't be moved yet, so I disabled it.

I was also seeing some weird behaviour with the icons not updating and fixed that.

Finally, I noticed that there's a loss of precision when calling ComponentInspector.OnPose. Even though double types are being used on both the QML and the C++, when the number gets to C++ it's truncated. I researched a bit and it sounded like Qt5 should be doing the right thing, unless we compiled with the -qreal float option, which I think we didn't. I didn't look any further and left a TODO in the code.

Some of the things I tried, for the record:

  • Forcing the side panel to expand as needed by the current numbers being displayed. It turned out to be complicated to propagate the desired width all the way from Pose3d.qml to the panel.
  • Eliding the numbers - I started looking deep into the child components of SpinBox and ended up so deep, and accessing so many "private" members, that I think it would be risky to rely on this.
  • Storing the actual number and the "display" number separately. The logic became quite involved, and in the end the behaviour may take users by surprised. I was storing the decimals that were hidden, and if the user edited the box when less decimals were displayed, I'd append those decimals to the command. But what if the user really meant to clean up those?

content.raw: oh no, these are all bad. I'll take another look.
content.html: oh no, these are all bad. I'll take another look.

content.raw:
great `-250` now displays displays fine.  One thing to confirm: if I try to change the number to say `-250.55`, I can only enter the decimal point `.` but not the decimal numbers. I need to drag the component inspector wider until the decimal points appear in order to enter them. Just checking if that’s the intended usage?

Another issue is that when testing with this pose: `<pose>0.258 0.15 0.23 0.1 0.2 0.3</pose>`. It shows up as all 0s in the pose inspector and if I hit enter, it resets the model pose to 0
content.html:
great -250 now displays displays fine. One thing to confirm: if I try to change the number to say -250.55, I can only enter the decimal point . but not the decimal numbers. I need to drag the component inspector wider until the decimal points appear in order to enter them. Just checking if that’s the intended usage?

Another issue is that when testing with this pose: <pose>0.258 0.15 0.23 0.1 0.2 0.3</pose>. It shows up as all 0s in the pose inspector and if I hit enter, it resets the model pose to 0

content.raw:
I think I improved the situation a bit on bf328c8 by changing the number of decimals.

The first thing I tried was to force the side panel to grow if the number doesn't fit, but it was too complicated to propagate the desired width all the way up from the spinbox to the menu.

So I settled with the decimals approach. Some caveats:

* Large numbers will still disappear to the left, but `-250` should work :grimacing:
* Different fields may end up with a different number of decimals, so they're not aligned

Some other things to consider in the future:

* Elide large numbers
* Align-left so the sign is visible, but we lose the numbers to the right

![decimals.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/732594957-decimals.gif)
content.html:
I think I improved the situation a bit on bf328c8 by changing the number of decimals.

The first thing I tried was to force the side panel to grow if the number doesn't fit, but it was too complicated to propagate the desired width all the way up from the spinbox to the menu.

So I settled with the decimals approach. Some caveats:

  • Large numbers will still disappear to the left, but -250 should work
  • Different fields may end up with a different number of decimals, so they're not aligned

Some other things to consider in the future:

  • Elide large numbers
  • Align-left so the sign is visible, but we lose the numbers to the right
